]0;seguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490: ~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[01;32mseguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490[00m:[01;34m~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[00m$ help cd*
Ã“rdenes de intÃ©rprete que coinciden con la palabra `cd*'

cd: cd [-L|[-P [-e]] [-@]] [dir]
    Cambia el directorio de trabajo del intÃ©rprete de comandos.
    
    Cambia el directorio actual a DIR.  El DIR por defecto es el valor de la
    variable HOME del intÃ©rprete.
    
    La variable CDPATH define la ruta de bÃºsqueda para el directorio que contiene
    DIR.  Los nombres de directorio alternativos en CDPATH se separan con dos puntos (:).
    Un nombre de directorio nulo es equivalente al directorio actual.  Si DIR comienza
    con un barra (/), entonces CDPATH no se usa.
    
    Si no se encuentra el directorio y se establece la opciÃ³n del intÃ©rprete Â«cdable_varsÂ»,
    se asume que la palabra es un nombre de variable.  Si esa variable tiene un valor,
    se utiliza ese valor para DIR.
    
    Opciones:
      -L	fuerza a seguir enlaces simbÃ³licos: resuelve enlaces
    		simbÃ³licos en DIR despuÃ©s de procesar instancias de Â«..Â»
      -P	usa la estructura del directorio fÃ­sico sin seguir
    		enlaces simbÃ³licos: resuelve enlaces simbÃ³licos en DIR antes
    		de procesar instancias de Â«..Â»
      -e	si se proporciona la opciÃ³n -P, y el directorio de trabajo
    		actual no se puede determinar correctamente, sale con
    		un estado distinto de cero
      -@	en sistemas que lo soportan, presenta un archivo con atributos
    		extendidos como un directorio que contiene los atributos de archivo
    
    Lo predeterminado es seguir enlaces simbÃ³licos, como si Â«-LÂ» se hubiera especificado.
    Se procesa Â«..Â» eliminando el componente del nombre de ruta inmediatamente anterior
    detrÃ¡s de una barra o al comienzo de DIR.
    
    Estado de salida:
    Devuelve 0 si se ha cambiado el directorio, y si $PWD se estableciÃ³ correctamente al
    utilizar -P; de otra manera es distinto de cero.

[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# Simple Root CA

# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from
# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
# than one openssl command.

[ default ]
ca                      = root-ca               # CA name
dir                     = .                     # Top dir

# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.
# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
# certificate.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = ca_dn                 # DN section
req_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions

[ ca_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "org"
1.domainComponent       = "simple"
organizationName        = "Simple Inc"
organizationalUnitName  = "Simple Root CA"
commonName              = "Simple Root CA"

[ ca_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
basicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash

# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# applying to the CA.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ ca_reqext ]
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcommonName              = "Simple Root CA"

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM0.domainComponent       = "org"
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ ca_dn ]

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMreq_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdistinguished_name      = ca_dn                 # DN section
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMprompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMstring_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMutf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMencrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ req ]
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# certificate.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdir                     = .                     # Top dir
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMca                      = root-ca               # CA name
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ default ]

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from

[KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# applying to the CA.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_ca              = root_ca               # The default CA section
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 3652                  # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = none                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = signing_ca_ext        # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 365                   # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ signing_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true,pathlen:0
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# CRL extensions exist solely to point to the CA certificate that has issued
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# the CRL.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ crl_ext ]

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# certificate.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdir                     = .                     # Top dir

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ default ]

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# than one openssl command.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from

[KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# applying to the CA.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_ca              = root_ca               # The default CA section
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 3652                  # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = none                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = signing_ca_ext        # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 365                   # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ signing_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true,pathlen:0
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# CRL extensions exist solely to point to the CA certificate that has issued
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# the CRL.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMencrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# certificate.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more

[KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# applying to the CA.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_ca              = root_ca               # The default CA section
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 3652                  # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = none                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = signing_ca_ext        # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 365                   # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ signing_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true,pathlen:0
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# CRL extensions exist solely to point to the CA certificate that has issued
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# the CRL.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ crl_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always

[10Phelp cd*[1Pcd etc/[Kcd pki-example-1/git clone https://bitbucket.org/stefanholek/pki-example-1cd pki-example-1/[K[Kcd etc/help cd*less root-ca.conf [Kless root-ca.conf 
[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# Simple Root CA

# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from
# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
# than one openssl command.

[ default ]
ca                      = root-ca               # CA name
dir                     = .                     # Top dir

# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.
# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
# certificate.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = ca_dn                 # DN section
req_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions

[ ca_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "org"
1.domainComponent       = "simple"
organizationName        = "Simple Inc"
organizationalUnitName  = "Simple Root CA"
commonName              = "Simple Root CA"

[ ca_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
basicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash

# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.
[7mroot-ca.conf[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l[23;0;0t]0;seguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490: ~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[01;32mseguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490[00m:[01;34m~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[00m$ hl[Kelp less*
Ã“rdenes de intÃ©rprete que coinciden con la palabra `less*'

bash: help: no hay temas de ayuda que coincidan con `less*'.  Pruebe `help help' o `man -k less*' o `info less*'.

Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[21;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals. Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[4;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[5;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[8;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[9;1H[K[10;1HCOMMANDS[11;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[12;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       h or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[15;1H[K[16;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[17;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[18;15Hful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[19;1H[K[20;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[21;1H[K[22;1H       ESC-SPACE[23;8H       Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[24;1H[K[25;1H       ENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[26;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[27;1H[K[28;1H       d or ^D[29;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[30;15Hand u commands.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[33;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[34;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       Less  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[36;1H[36;1H[2;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[3;1H[K[4;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[5;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[7;1HCOMMANDS[K[8;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[9;1H       sequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[10;1H[K[11;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[14;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[15;1H              ful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[16;1H[K[17;8Hz      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       ESC-SPACE[20;8H       Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[22;9HNTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[23;15HScroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[25;8Hd or ^D[K[26;47Hone half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[27;1H              and u commands.[28;1H[K[29;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[30;15HScroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[31;1H              screenful is displayed.[32;1H[K[33;8Hw      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[36;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[36;1H[1;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below. The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[23;1H[K[24;1H       d or ^D[25;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[26;15Hand u commands.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[29;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[30;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[33;1H[K[34;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[35;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[36;15Hsome systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines -- 2%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[28;15Hd and u commands.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[31;1H[K[32;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[33;1H[K[34;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[35;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option). If a number N is specified, it[23;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       ESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[26;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[27;1H[K[28;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[29;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[30;1H[K[31;1H       r or ^R or ^L[32;8H       Repaint the screen.[33;1H[K[34;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[35;1H[K[36;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[3;1H              some systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[4;1H[K[5;8Hu or ^U[K[6;15HScroll backward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[7;1H              d and u commands.[8;1H[K[9;8HJ      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[K[10;1H[K[11;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[12;1H[K[13;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[14;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[15;1H              becomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.  While the text is scrolled, it  acts  as  though  the  -S[16;8H       option (chop lines) were in effect.[17;1H[K[18;8HESC-( or LEFTARROW[K[19;15HScroll  horizontally  left  N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[20;1H              becomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.[21;1H[K[22;8HESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[K[23;15HScroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[25;12H{ or ^LEFTARROW[K[26;35Hleft back to the first column.[K[28;8Hr or ^R or ^L[K[29;15HRepaint the screen.[K[31;8HR      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[32;1H[K[33;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[34;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[35;1H              is similar to the "tail -f" command.)[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1. (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[24;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[26;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[27;15Hbuffered.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[30;1H[K[31;8HP      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[33;8H{      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[34;1H              bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[35;8H       curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[2;1H[K[3;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[4;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[5;1H[K[6;1H       r or ^R or ^L[7;8H       Repaint the screen.[8;1H[K[9;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[10;1H[K[11;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[12;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[13;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[14;1H[K[15;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[16;8H       scrolling stops.[K[17;1H[K[18;1H       g or < or ESC-<[19;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[20;1H[K[21;1H       G or > or ESC->[22;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[23;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       ESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[26;8H       buffered.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[29;1H[K[30;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[31;1H[K[32;1H       {      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[33;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[34;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[36;1H[36;1H[3;8Hr or ^R or ^L[K[4;15HRepaint the screen.[K[6;8HR      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input. Normally this command would be used  when  already[9;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed. N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[10;1H[K[11;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[12;1H[K[13;1H       {      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[14;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[15;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[18;8H       curly bracket.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[19;15Hright curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       (      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[22;1H[K[23;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[24;1H[K[25;1H       [      Like {, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[26;1H[K[27;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[28;1H[K[29;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[30;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[33;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       G or > or ESC->[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[4;15Hbuffered.[K[6;8Hp or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[9;1H[K[10;1H       {      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[11;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[12;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[13;1H[K[14;8H}      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[15;28H.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[16;1H              right curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[17;1H[K[18;8H(      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[K[19;1H[K[20;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[21;1H[K[22;1H       [      Like {, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[23;1H[K[24;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[25;1H[K[26;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[27;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[29;13HB Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[30;21HB < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[32;8Hm      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[35;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[36;1H              by  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively. For example,[19;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[22;1H[K[23;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[24;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[25;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[26;15Hthe ' command can be used to switch between input files.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       ^X^X   Same as single quote.[29;1H[K[30;1H       /pattern[31;8H       Search forward in the file for the N-th line containing the pattern.  N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[32;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system.  The search starts at the first line displayed (but[33;15Hsee the -a and -j options, which change this).[K[34;1H[K[35;1H              Certain characters are special if entered at the beginning of the pattern; they modify the type of search rather than become[36;15Hpart of the pattern:[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[3;8H       curly bracket. N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[21;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system.  The search starts at the first line displayed (but[22;15Hsee the -a and -j options, which change this).[K[23;1H[K[24;1H              Certain characters are special if entered at the beginning of the pattern; they modify the type of search rather than become[25;15Hpart of the pattern:[K[26;1H[K[27;1H              ^N or ![28;15H       Search for lines which do NOT match the pattern.[29;1H[K[30;1H              ^E or *[31;15H       Search  multiple  files.   That  is,  if  the search reaches the END of the current file without finding a match, the[32;22Hsearch continues in the next file in the command line list.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H              ^F or @[35;15H       Begin the search at the first line of the FIRST file in the command line list, regardless of what is  currently  disâ€[36;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[2;1H[K[3;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[4;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[5;1H[K[6;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[7;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[8;1H[K[9;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[10;1H[K[11;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[12;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[13;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[14;15Hthe ' command can be used to switch between input files.[K[15;1H[K[16;1H       ^X^X   Same as single quote.[17;1H[K[18;1H       /pattern[19;8H       Search forward in the file for the N-th line containing the pattern.  N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[20;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system.  The search starts at the first line displayed (but[21;15Hsee the -a and -j options, which change this).[K[22;1H[K[23;1H              Certain characters are special if entered at the beginning of the pattern; they modify the type of search rather than become[24;15Hpart of the pattern:[K[25;1H[K[26;1H              ^N or ![27;15H       Search for lines which do NOT match the pattern.[28;1H[K[29;1H              ^E or *[30;15H       Search  multiple  files.   That  is,  if  the search reaches the END of the current file without finding a match, the[31;22Hsearch continues in the next file in the command line list.[K[32;1H[K[33;1H              ^F or @[34;15H       Begin the search at the first line of the FIRST file in the command line list, regardless of what is  currently  disâ€[35;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[3;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[6;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[9;1H[K[10;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[11;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[12;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively. Followed[33;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[34;15Hthe ' command can be used to switch between input files.[36;8H^X^X   Same as single quote.[1;1H[1;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[2;1H              buffered.[3;1H[K[4;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[5;1H[K[6;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[7;1H[K[8;8H{      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[9;15Hbracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[10;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[11;1H[K[12;8H}      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[13;15Hcurly bracket.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[14;1H              right curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[15;1H[K[16;1H       (      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[17;1H[K[18;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[19;1H[K[20;1H       [      Like {, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[21;1H[K[22;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[23;1H[K[24;8HESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[25;1H              "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[26;1H[K[27;8HESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[28;1H              "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[29;1H[K[30;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[31;1H[K[32;8H'      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[33;15HFollowed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[34;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[35;1H              the ' command can be used to switch between input files.[36;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H              and standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;15HGo  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;8HG or > or ESC->[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H              Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file). If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[26;1H[K[27;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[28;15HScroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[29;1H              ful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[30;1H[K[31;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[32;1H[K[33;8HESC-SPACE[K[34;1H              Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[35;1H[K[36;8HENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1HSYNOPSIS[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H       less - opposite of more[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1HNAME[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --Top-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1HLESS(1)                                                   General Commands Manual                                                  LESS(1)[1;1H[1;1H[2;1H[K[3;1HNAME[K[4;14H opposite of more[5;1H[K[6;1HSYNOPSIS[K[7;8Hless -?[K[8;8Hless --help[K[9;8Hless -V[K[10;8Hless --version[K[11;1H       less [-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][12;1H            [-b space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][13;8H     [-{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][K[14;8H     [-T tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][K[15;8H     [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[16;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[K[18;1HDESCRIPTION[K[19;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[20;1H       starting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[21;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[22;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[25;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[27;1HCOMMANDS[K[28;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[34;15Hand u commands.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15H# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1HDESCRIPTION[K[3;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[4;1H       starting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[5;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[6;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[7;1H[K[8;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[9;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[11;1HCOMMANDS[K[12;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[13;1H       sequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[14;1H[K[15;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[18;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[19;1H              ful is displayed. The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[29;8Hd or ^D[K[30;47Hone half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[31;1H              and u commands.[32;1H[K[33;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[34;15HScroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[35;1H              screenful is displayed.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;1HDESCRIPTION[2;1H       Less  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[33;15Hd and u commands.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[35;1H[35;1H[35;1H[34;1H[34;1H[34;1H[33;1H[33;1H[33;1H[32;1H[32;1H[32;1H[31;1H[31;1H[31;1H[30;1H[30;1H[30;1H[29;1H[29;1H[29;1H[28;1H[28;1H[28;1H[27;1H[27;1H[27;1H[26;1H[26;1H[26;1H[25;1H[25;1H[25;1H[24;1H[24;1H[24;1H[23;1H[23;1H[23;1H[22;1H[22;1H[22;1H[21;1H[21;1H[21;1H[20;1H[20;1H[20;1H[19;1H[19;1H[19;1H[18;1H[18;1H[18;1H[17;1H[17;1H[17;1H[16;1H[16;1H[16;1H[15;1H[15;1H[15;1H[14;1H[14;1H[14;1H[13;1H[13;1H[13;1H[12;1H[12;1H[12;1H[11;1H[11;1H[11;1H[10;1H[10;1H[10;1H[9;1H[9;1H[9;1H[8;1H[8;1H[8;1H[7;1H[7;1H[7;1H[6;1H[6;1H[6;1H[5;1H[5;1H[5;1H[4;1H[4;1H[4;1H[3;1H[3;1H[3;1H[2;1H[2;1H[2;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X. Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[4;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[5;1H[K[6;1HCOMMANDS[K[7;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X. If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[11;1H[K[12;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[13;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below). Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[15;1H[K[16;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[17;1H[K[18;8HESC-SPACE[K[19;15HLike SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[21;8HENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[22;22Hforward N lines, default 1. (On a hardcopy terminal,[20;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[21;1H[K[22;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[23;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[24;1H[K[25;1HCOMMANDS[26;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[27;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       h or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[30;1H[K[31;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[32;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[33;15Hful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       less - opposite of more[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1HSYNOPSIS[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       less -?[36;1H[36;1H[2;14H-help[K[3;1H       less -V[4;1H       less --version[5;13H[-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][6;8H     [-b space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][7;8H     [-{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][8;8H     [-T tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][9;8H     [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[10;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[11;1H[K[12;1HDESCRIPTION[K[13;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[14;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[15;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[16;1H       lines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[17;1H[K[18;8HCommands are based on both more and vi. If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[26;1H[K[27;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[28;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below). Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[31;8Hz      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[32;1H[K[33;8HESC-SPACE[K[34;1H              Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[35;1H[K[36;1H       ENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[36;1H[1;14H-help[2;14HV[K[3;14H-version[4;13H[-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][5;8H     [-b space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][6;15H{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][7;15HT tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][8;15H# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[9;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[10;1H[K[11;1HDESCRIPTION[12;1H       Less  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features. The[3;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[4;1H[K[5;1HCOMMANDS[K[6;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[7;1H       sequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[8;1H[K[9;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[11;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[12;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[13;8H       ful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[14;1H[K[15;8Hz      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[K[17;8HESC-SPACE[K[18;1H              Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[19;1H[K[20;8HENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[K[21;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[22;1H[K[23;8Hd or ^D[K[24;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[25;8H       and u commands.[26;1H[K[27;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[28;1H              Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[29;8H       screenful is displayed.[30;1H[K[31;8Hw      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[33;8Hy or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[K[34;1H              Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[28;15Hd and u commands.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[31;1H[K[32;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[33;1H[K[34;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[35;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[36;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.  While the text is scrolled, it  acts  as  though  the  -S[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[4;1H[K[5;1H       ESC-SPACE[6;8H       Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[7;1H[K[8;1H       ENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[9;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[10;1H[K[11;1H       d or ^D[12;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[13;15Hand u commands.[K[14;1H[K[15;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[16;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[17;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[20;1H[K[21;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[22;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[23;15Hsome systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       u or ^U[26;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[27;15Hd and u commands.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[30;1H[K[31;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[32;1H[K[33;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[34;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[35;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.  While the text is scrolled, it  acts  as  though  the  -S[36;15Hoption (chop lines) were in effect.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[35;1H[35;1H[35;1H[34;1H[34;1H[34;1H[33;1H[33;1H[33;1H[32;1H[32;1H[32;1H[31;1H[31;1H[31;1H[30;1H[30;1H[30;1H[29;1H[29;1H[29;1H[28;1H[28;1H[28;1H[27;1H[27;1H[27;1H[26;1H[26;1H[26;1H[25;1H[25;1H[25;1H[24;1H[24;1H[24;1H[23;1H[23;1H[23;1H[22;1H[22;1H[22;1H[21;1H[21;1H[21;1H[20;1H[20;1H[20;1H[19;1H[19;1H[19;1H[18;1H[18;1H[18;1H[17;1H[17;1H[17;1H[16;1H[16;1H[16;1H[15;1H[15;1H[15;1H[14;1H[14;1H[14;1H[13;1H[13;1H[13;1H[12;1H[12;1H[12;1H[11;1H[11;1H[11;1H[10;1H[10;1H[10;1H[9;1H[9;1H[9;1H[8;1H[8;1H[8;1H[7;1H[7;1H[7;1H[6;1H[6;1H[6;1H[5;1H[5;1H[5;1H[4;1H[4;1H[4;1H[3;1H[3;1H[3;1H[2;1H[2;1H[2;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;15HScroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below). Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[34;1H[K[35;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[36;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --Top-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1HLESS(1)                                                   General Commands Manual                                                  LESS(1)[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[2;1H[K[3;1HNAME[4;1H       less - opposite of more[5;1H[K[6;1HSYNOPSIS[K[7;14H?[8;15Hhelp[K[9;13H-V[K[10;8Hless --version[K[11;8Hless [-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][K[12;15Hb space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][K[13;15H{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][14;8H     [-T tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][K[15;1H            [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[16;1H       (See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[17;1H[K[18;1HDESCRIPTION[K[19;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[20;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[21;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[22;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[25;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[26;1H[K[27;1HCOMMANDS[K[28;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[29;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[31;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[32;1H[K[33;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[34;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[35;8H       ful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[2;1H[2;1H[2;1H[3;1H[3;1H[3;1H[4;1H[4;1H[4;1H[5;1H[5;1H[5;1H[6;1H[6;1H[6;1H[7;1H[7;1H[7;1H[8;1H[8;1H[8;1H[9;1H[9;1H[9;1H[10;1H[10;1H[10;1H[11;1H[11;1H[11;1H[12;1H[12;1H[12;1H[13;1H[13;1H[13;1H[14;1H[14;1H[14;1H[15;1H[15;1H[15;1H[16;1H[16;1H[16;1H[17;1H[17;1H[17;1H[18;1H[18;1H[18;1H[19;1H[19;1H[19;1H[20;1H[20;1H[20;1H[21;1H[21;1H[21;1H[22;1H[22;1H[22;1H[23;1H[23;1H[23;1H[24;1H[24;1H[24;1H[25;1H[25;1H[25;1H[26;1H[26;1H[26;1H[27;1H[27;1H[27;1H[28;1H[28;1H[28;1H[29;1H[29;1H[29;1H[30;1H[30;1H[30;1H[31;1H[31;1H[31;1H[32;1H[32;1H[32;1H[33;1H[33;1H[33;1H[34;1H[34;1H[34;1H[35;1H[35;1H[35;1H[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines -- 0%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1HNAME[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       less - If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[34;15Hand u commands.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15H# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;1HDESCRIPTION[K[4;1H       Less  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[5;1H       starting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[6;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[7;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[8;1H[K[9;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[10;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[11;1H[K[12;1HCOMMANDS[K[13;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[14;1H       sequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[15;1H[K[16;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[18;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[19;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[20;8H       ful is displayed. The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[29;1H[K[30;8Hd or ^D[K[31;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size. Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[34;1H[K[35;8Hz      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[K[36;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[K[2;1HNAME[K[3;1H       less - opposite of more[4;1H[K[5;1HSYNOPSIS[K[6;14H?[K[7;14H-help[8;14HV[K[9;13H--version[K[10;8Hless [-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][K[11;15Hb space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][K[12;15H{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][K[13;15HT tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][14;8H     [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[15;1H       (See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[16;1H[K[17;1HDESCRIPTION[K[18;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[19;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sysâ€[20;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[21;1H       lines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[22;1H[K[23;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[24;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[25;1H[K[26;1HCOMMANDS[K[27;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X. The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[24;8Hd or ^D[K[25;15HScroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[26;1H              and u commands.[27;1H[K[28;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[29;1H              Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[30;8H       screenful is displayed.[31;1H[K[32;8Hw      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[34;8Hy or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[35;22H backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[36;16Home systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[3;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[4;1H[K[5;1HCOMMANDS[6;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[7;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[8;1H[K[9;1H       h or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[10;1H[K[11;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[12;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screenâ€[13;15Hful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[14;1H[K[15;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[16;1H[K[17;1H       ESC-SPACE[18;8H       Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[19;1H[K[20;1H       ENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[21;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[22;1H[K[23;1H       d or ^D[24;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[25;15Hand u commands.[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[28;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[29;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[30;1H[K[31;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[32;1H[K[33;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[34;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size. Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[28;8HF      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[29;15Hat the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[30;1H              is similar to the "tail -f" command.)[31;1H[K[32;8HESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[33;1H              scrolling stops.[34;1H[K[35;8Hg or < or ESC-<[K[36;15HGo to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).
