Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[26;1H[K[27;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[28;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[29;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[30;1H[K[31;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[32;8H       scrolling stops.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       g or < or ESC-<[35;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file). (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[31;8HG or > or ESC->[K[32;15HGo  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[33;1H              and standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[34;1H[K[35;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[36;1H              buffered.[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option). Normally this command would be used  when  already[21;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[22;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[25;8H       scrolling stops.[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       g or < or ESC-<[28;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[29;1H[K[30;1H       G or > or ESC->[31;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[32;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       ESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[35;8H       buffered.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands. If a number N is specified, it[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8HESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[K[3;15HScroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[5;12H{ or ^LEFTARROW[6;22Hhorizontally left back to the first column.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       r or ^R or ^L[9;8H       Repaint the screen.[10;1H[K[11;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[12;1H[K[13;8HF      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[14;1H              at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[15;8H       is similar to the "tail -f" command.)[16;1H[K[17;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[18;8H       scrolling stops.[K[20;8Hg or < or ESC-<[K[21;15HGo to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[K[22;1H[K[23;1H       G or > or ESC->[24;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[25;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[27;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[28;15Hbuffered.[K[30;8Hp or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[31;1H[K[32;8HP      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[K[34;8H{      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[35;16Hracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[36;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[2;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[3;1H[K[4;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[5;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[6;1H[K[7;1H       r or ^R or ^L[8;8H       Repaint the screen.[9;1H[K[10;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[11;1H[K[12;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[13;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[14;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[15;1H[K[16;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[17;8H       scrolling stops.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       g or < or ESC-<[20;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[21;1H[K[22;1H       G or > or ESC->[23;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[24;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[25;1H[K[26;1H       ESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[27;8H       buffered.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[30;1H[K[31;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[32;1H[K[33;1H       {      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[34;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[35;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines -- 7%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H       r or ^R or ^L[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Repaint the screen.[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input. The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[28;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[29;1H[K[30;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[31;8H       curly bracket.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[32;1H              right curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[33;1H[K[34;8H(      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input. For example,[28;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[31;1H[K[32;8H'      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[33;1H              Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[34;8H       by  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[35;1H              the ' command can be used to switch between input files.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;8H       buffered.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file. For example,[18;1H              "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[19;1H[K[20;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[21;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[23;8Hm      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[26;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[27;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[28;1H              the ' command can be used to switch between input files.[29;1H[K[30;1H       ^X^X   Same as single quote.[31;1H[K[32;8H/pattern[K[33;15HSearch forward in the file for the N-th line containing the pattern.  N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[34;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system. The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[2;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[5;8H       curly bracket. If  there  is  more  than  one[6;15Hright curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       (      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[9;1H[K[10;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[11;1H[K[12;1H       [      Like {, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[13;1H[K[14;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[15;1H[K[16;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively. The search starts at the first line displayed (but[20;15Hsee the -a and -j options, which change this).[K[21;1H[K[22;1H              Certain characters are special if entered at the beginning of the pattern; they modify the type of search rather than become[23;15Hpart of the pattern:[K[24;1H[K[25;1H              ^N or ![26;15H       Search for lines which do NOT match the pattern.[27;1H[K[28;1H              ^E or *[29;15H       Search  multiple  files.   That  is,  if  the search reaches the END of the current file without finding a match, the[30;22Hsearch continues in the next file in the command line list.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H              ^F or @[33;15H       Begin the search at the first line of the FIRST file in the command line list, regardless of what is  currently  disâ€[34;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H              ^K     Highlight  any  text which matches the pattern on the current screen, but don't move to the first match (KEEP current[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[2;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[5;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[8;1H[K[9;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[10;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[11;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively. If the previous search was modified by ^N, the search is[32;1H              made for the N-th line NOT containing the pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[33;15Hnext (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file.  If the previous search was modified by ^R, the search is done[34;1H              without using regular expressions. There is no effect if the previous search was modified by ^F or ^K.[24;1H[K[25;8HN      Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction.[27;12Hn  Repeat previous search, but crossing file boundaries.  The effect is as if the previous search were modified by *.[28;1H[K[29;1H       ESC-N  Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction and crossing file boundaries.[30;1H[K[31;8HESC-u  Undo search highlighting.  Turn off highlighting of strings matching the current search pattern.  If highlighting is already[32;15Hoff because of a previous ESC-u command, turn highlighting back on.  Any search command will also turn highlighting back on.[33;15H(Highlighting can also be disabled by toggling the -G option; in that case search commands do  not  turn  highlighting  back[34;1H              on.)[35;1H[K[36;1H       &pattern[36;1H[1;1H              ^E or *[2;15H       Search multiple files.  That is, if the search reaches the beginning of the current file without finding a match, the[3;22Hsearch continues in the previous file in the command line list.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H              ^F or @[6;15H       Begin the search at the last line of the last file in the command line list, regardless of  what  is  currently  disâ€[7;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[8;1H[K[9;1H              ^K     As in forward searches.[10;1H[K[11;1H              ^R     As in forward searches.[12;1H[K[13;1H       ESC-/pattern[14;8H       Same as "/*".[15;1H[K[16;1H       ESC-?pattern[17;8H       Same as "?*".[18;1H[K[19;1H       n      Repeat previous search, for N-th line containing the last pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^N, the search is[20;8H       made for the N-th line NOT containing the pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[21;15Hnext (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file.  If the previous search was modified by ^R, the search is done[22;15Hwithout using regular expressions.  There is no effect if the previous search was modified by ^F or ^K.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       N      Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction.[25;1H[K[26;1H       ESC-n  Repeat previous search, but crossing file boundaries.  The effect is as if the previous search were modified by *.[27;1H[K[28;1H       ESC-N  Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction and crossing file boundaries.[29;1H[K[30;1H       ESC-u  Undo search highlighting.  Turn off highlighting of strings matching the current search pattern.  If highlighting is already[31;8H       off because of a previous ESC-u command, turn highlighting back on. If a ^P (CONTROL-P) is entered immediately after the dash, the setting of the[35;15Hoption is changed but no message is printed.  If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[36;15H(such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --19%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;8H       Examine  a  new  file.   If  the filename is missing, the "current" file (see the :n and :p commands below) from the list of[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hfiles in the command line is re-examined.  A percent sign (%) in the filename is replaced by the name of the  current  file.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15HA pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  However, two consecutive percent signs are simply[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hreplaced with a single percent sign.  This allows you to enter a filename that contains a percent sign in the  name.   Simiâ€[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hlarly,  two  consecutive  pound signs are replaced with a single pound sign.  The filename is inserted into the command line[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;16Hist of files so that it can be seen by subsequent :n and :p commands.  If the filename consists of several files, they  are[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hall  inserted into the list of files and the first one is examined.  If the filename contains one or more spaces, the entire[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hfilename should be enclosed in double quotes (also see the -" option).[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;8H^X^V or E[K[4;15HSame as :e.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.  On such systems, you may not  be  able  to[5;15Huse ^V.[K[6;1H[K[7;8H:n     Examine the next file (from the list of files given in the command line).  If a number N is specified, the N-th next file is[8;15Hexamined.[K[9;1H[K[10;1H       :p     Examine the previous file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th previous file is examined.[11;1H[K[12;8H:x     Examine the first file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th file in the list is examined.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       :d     Remove the current file from the list of files.[15;1H[K[16;8Ht      Go to the next tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.  See the -t option for more details about tags.[18;8HT      Go to the previous tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.[K[20;8H= or ^G or :f[K[21;1H              Prints some information about the file being viewed, including its name and the line number and byte offset  of  the  bottom[22;8H       line  being  displayed.  If possible, it also prints the length of the file, the number of lines in the file and the percent[23;1H              of the file above the last displayed line.[24;1H[K[25;1H       -      Followed by one of the command line option letters (see OPTIONS below), this will change the  setting  of  that  option  and[26;8H       print  a  message describing the new setting.  If a ^P (CONTROL-P) is entered immediately after the dash, the setting of the[27;1H              option is changed but no message is printed.  If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[28;8H       (such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[29;15Hthe current setting is printed and nothing is changed.[K[30;1H[K[31;8H--     Like the - command, but takes a long option name (see OPTIONS below) rather than a single option  letter.   You  must  press[32;1H              ENTER  or  RETURN  after  typing  the  option name.  A ^P immediately after the second dash suppresses printing of a message[33;8H       describing the new setting, as in the - command.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-+     Followed by one of the command line option letters this will reset the option to its default setting  and  print  a  message[36;15Hdescribing  the  new setting.  (The "-+X" command does the same thing as "-+X" on the command line.)  This does not work for[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       ^X^V or E[3;8H       Same as :e. A ^P immediately after the second dash suppresses printing of a message[13;8H       describing the new setting, as in the - command.[K[14;1H[K[15;8H-+     Followed by one of the command line option letters this will reset the option to its default setting  and  print  a  message[16;1H              describing  the  new setting.  (The "-+X" command does the same thing as "-+X" on the command line.)  This does not work for[17;8H       string-valued options.[K[18;1H[K[19;8H--+    Like the -+ command, but takes a long option name rather than a single option letter.[21;9H!     Followed by one of the command line option letters, this will reset the option to the "opposite" of its default setting  and[22;1H              print a message describing the new setting.  This does not work for numeric or string-valued options.[23;1H[K[24;8H--!    Like the -! command, but takes a long option name rather than a single option letter.[K[26;8H_      (Underscore.)   Followed by one of the command line option letters, this will print a message describing the current setting[27;1H              of that option.  The setting of the option is not changed.[28;1H[K[29;8H__     (Double underscore.)  Like the _ (underscore) command, but takes a long option name rather than a single option letter.  You[30;1H              must press ENTER or RETURN after typing the option name.[31;1H[K[32;8H+cmd   Causes  the specified cmd to be executed each time a new file is examined.  For example, +G causes less to initially display[33;1H              each file starting at the end rather than the beginning.[34;1H[K[35;8HV      Prints the version number of less being run.[K[36;1H[1;15Hline  being  displayed.  If possible, it also prints the length of the file, the number of lines in the file and the percent[2;15Hof the file above the last displayed line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       -      Followed by one of the command line option letters (see OPTIONS below), this will change the  setting  of  that  option  and[5;8H       print  a  message describing the new setting.  If a ^P (CONTROL-P) is entered immediately after the dash, the setting of the[6;15Hoption is changed but no message is printed.  If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[7;15H(such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[8;15Hthe current setting is printed and nothing is changed.[K[9;1H[K[10;1H       --     Like the - command, but takes a long option name (see OPTIONS below) rather than a single option  letter.   You  must  press[11;8H       ENTER  or  RETURN  after  typing  the  option name.  A ^P immediately after the second dash suppresses printing of a message[12;15Hdescribing the new setting, as in the - command.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       -+     Followed by one of the command line option letters this will reset the option to its default setting  and  print  a  message[15;8H       describing  the  new setting.  (The "-+X" command does the same thing as "-+X" on the command line.)  This does not work for[16;15Hstring-valued options.[K[17;1H[K[18;1H       --+    Like the -+ command, but takes a long option name rather than a single option letter.[19;1H[K[20;1H       -! A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[33;1H              file.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[34;8H       with no shell command simply invokes a shell. Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[31;15Hbe piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[32;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[33;1H[K[34;8Hs filename[K[35;1H              Save the input to a file. On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[19;1H[K[20;8H| <m> shell-command[K[21;1H              <m>  represents  any mark letter.  Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[22;8H       be piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[23;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[24;1H[K[25;8Hs filename[K[26;15HSave the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[K[28;1HOPTIONS[K[29;8HCommand line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[K[30;1H[K[31;8HMost  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[32;1H       name.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbreâ€[33;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[34;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[35;1H       of the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       V      Prints the version number of less being run.[3;1H[K[4;1H       q or Q or :q or :Q or ZZ[5;8H       Exits less.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       The following four commands may or may not be valid, depending on your particular installation.[8;1H[K[9;1H       v      Invokes an editor to edit the current file being viewed.  The editor is  taken  from  the  environment  variable  VISUAL  if[10;8H       defined, or EDITOR if VISUAL is not defined, or defaults to "vi" if neither VISUAL nor EDITOR is defined.  See also the disâ€[11;15Hcussion of LESSEDIT under the section on PROMPTS below.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       ! shell-command[14;8H       Invokes a shell to run the shell-command given.  A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[15;15Hfile.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[16;15Hwith no shell command simply invokes a shell.  On Unix systems, the shell is taken from the environment variable  SHELL,  or[17;15Hdefaults to "sh".  On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       | <m> shell-command[20;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter.  Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[21;15Hbe piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[22;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       s filename[25;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[26;1H[K[27;1HOPTIONS[28;1H       Command line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[29;1H[K[30;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[31;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbreâ€[32;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[33;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[34;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       V      Prints the version number of less being run.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       q or Q or :q or :Q or ZZ[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Exits less.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       The following four commands may or may not be valid, depending on your particular installation.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8Hv      Invokes an editor to edit the current file being viewed.  The editor is  taken  from  the  environment  variable  VISUAL  if[3;1H              defined, or EDITOR if VISUAL is not defined, or defaults to "vi" if neither VISUAL nor EDITOR is defined.  See also the disâ€[4;8H       cussion of LESSEDIT under the section on PROMPTS below.[5;1H[K[6;1H       ! shell-command[7;8H       Invokes a shell to run the shell-command given.  A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[8;1H              file.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[9;8H       with no shell command simply invokes a shell.  On Unix systems, the shell is taken from the environment variable  SHELL,  or[10;18Haults to "sh".  On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[11;1H[K[12;1H       | <m> shell-command[13;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter.  Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[14;15Hbe piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[15;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[16;1H[K[17;8Hs filename[K[18;1H              Save the input to a file. If  an[32;1H       option  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[33;8Hwith "-+".[K[35;8HSome options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[36;1H       dollar sign ($) is found. A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbreâ€[15;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[16;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[17;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS". If  an[31;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[32;8Hwith "-+".[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter. This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[3;1H[K[4;1HOPTIONS[K[5;8HCommand line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[7;8HMost  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[8;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbreâ€[9;1H       viated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[10;1H       as --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[11;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[13;8HOptions  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[14;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[15;1H[K[16;8Hsetenv LESS "-options"[K[17;1H[K[18;1H       or if you use sh:[19;1H[K[20;8HLESS="-options"; export LESS[22;8HOn MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[24;8HThe environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[25;1H       option  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[26;8Hwith "-+".[K[28;8HSome options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[29;1H       dollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[30;1H[K[31;8HLESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[K[32;1H[K[33;1H       If  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[34;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[35;8Hspecially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[K[36;1H[1;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[2;1H[K[3;1HOPTIONS[4;1H       Command line options are described below. Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;8Hsetenv LESS "-options"[K[5;8Hor if you use sh:[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[8;1H[K[9;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[10;1H[K[11;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[12;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[13;1H       with "-+".[14;1H[K[15;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[16;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[17;1H[K[18;8HLESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[20;8HIf  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[21;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[22;1H       specially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[23;1H[K[24;1H       -? or --help[25;8H       This  option  displays a summary of the commands accepted by less (the same as the h command).  (Depending on how your shell[26;8H       interprets the question mark, it may be necessary to quote the question mark, thus: "-\?".)[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       -a or --search-skip-screen[29;8H       By default, forward searches start at the top of the displayed screen and backwards searches start at the bottom of the disâ€[30;15Hplayed  screen  (except  for repeated searches invoked by the n or N commands, which start after or before the "target" line[31;15Hrespectively; see the -j option for more about the target line).  The -a option causes forward searches to instead start  at[32;1H              the  bottom  of the screen and backward searches to start at the top of the screen, thus skipping all lines displayed on the[33;8H       screen.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[K[36;15HCauses all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       setenv LESS "-options"[3;1H[K[4;1H       or if you use sh:[5;1H[K[6;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[7;1H[K[8;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[9;1H[K[10;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[11;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[12;8Hwith "-+".[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[15;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       LESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[18;1H[K[19;1H       If  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[20;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[21;8Hspecially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[K[22;1H[K[23;1H       -? or --help[24;8H       This  option  displays a summary of the commands accepted by less (the same as the h command).  (Depending on how your shell[25;15Hinterprets the question mark, it may be necessary to quote the question mark, thus: "-\?".)[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       -a or --search-skip-screen[28;8H       By default, forward searches start at the top of the displayed screen and backwards searches start at the bottom of the disâ€[29;15Hplayed  screen  (except  for repeated searches invoked by the n or N commands, which start after or before the "target" line[30;15Hrespectively; see the -j option for more about the target line).  The -a option causes forward searches to instead start  at[31;15Hthe  bottom  of the screen and backward searches to start at the top of the screen, thus skipping all lines displayed on the[32;15Hscreen.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       -A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[35;8H       Causes all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[36;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       setenv LESS "-options"[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       or if you use sh:[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8HLESS="-options"; export LESS[4;8HOn MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[6;8HThe environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[7;1H       option  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[8;8Hwith "-+".[K[10;8HSome options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[11;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       LESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[14;1H[K[15;8HIf  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[16;1H       option string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[17;8Hspecially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[19;8H-? or --help[K[20;8H       This  option  displays a summary of the commands accepted by less (the same as the h command).  (Depending on how your shell[21;8H       interprets the question mark, it may be necessary to quote the question mark, thus: "-\?".)[23;9Ha or --search-skip-screen[24;15HBy default, forward searches start at the top of the displayed screen and backwards searches start at the bottom of the disâ€[25;15Hplayed  screen  (except  for repeated searches invoked by the n or N commands, which start after or before the "target" line[26;1H              respectively; see the -j option for more about the target line).  The -a option causes forward searches to instead start  at[27;8H       the  bottom  of the screen and backward searches to start at the top of the screen, thus skipping all lines displayed on the[28;15Hscreen.[K[29;1H[K[30;8H-A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[K[31;15HCauses all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[32;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[33;1H              to and including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[34;8H       including the target line.  This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[35;1H[K[36;8H-bn or --buffers=n[K[36;1H[1;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[2;1H[K[3;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[4;1H[K[5;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable. (Depending on how your shell[20;15Hinterprets the question mark, it may be necessary to quote the question mark, thus: "-\?".)[K[21;1H[K[22;1H       -a or --search-skip-screen[23;8H       By default, forward searches start at the top of the displayed screen and backwards searches start at the bottom of the disâ€[24;15Hplayed  screen  (except  for repeated searches invoked by the n or N commands, which start after or before the "target" line[25;15Hrespectively; see the -j option for more about the target line). Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[24;15Hto and including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[25;15Hincluding the target line.  This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[K[26;1H[K[27;8H-bn or --buffers=n[28;1H              Specifies  the  amount  of buffer space less will use for each file, in units of kilobytes (1024 bytes).  By default 64 K of[29;8H       buffer space is used for each file (unless the file is a pipe; see the -B option).  The -b option specifies instead  that  n[30;15Hkilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file.  If n is -1, buffer space is unlimited; that is, the entire file can[31;15Hbe read into memory.[K[32;1H[K[33;8H-B or --auto-buffers[K[34;1H              By default, when data is read from a pipe, buffers are allocated automatically as needed.  If a large amount of data is read[35;8H       from the pipe, this can cause a large amount of memory to be allocated.  The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[36;15Hbuffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe.  Warning: use[36;1H[1;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       LESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[4;1H[K[5;1H       If  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[6;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash. Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[23;18Hand including the target line). The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[18;15Hbuffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe.  Warning: use[19;15Hof  -B  can  result  in erroneous display, since only the most recently viewed part of the piped data is kept in memory; any[20;15Hearlier data is lost.[K[21;1H[K[22;1H       -c or --clear-screen[23;8H       Causes full screen repaints to be painted from the top line down.  By default, full screen repaints are  done  by  scrolling[24;15Hfrom the bottom of the screen.[K[25;1H[K[26;8H-C or --CLEAR-SCREEN[K[27;15HSame as -c, for compatibility with older versions of less.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       -d or --dumb[30;8H       The  -d  option suppresses the error message normally displayed if the terminal is dumb; that is, lacks some important capaâ€[31;15Hbility, such as the ability to clear the screen or scroll backward.  The -d option does not otherwise change the behavior of[32;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[34;9HDxcolor or --color=xcolor[35;15H[MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[36;1H              being set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period.   The[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       -A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[3;8H       Causes all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[4;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[5;18Hand including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[6;15Hincluding the target line.  This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       -bn or --buffers=n[9;8H       Specifies  the  amount  of buffer space less will use for each file, in units of kilobytes (1024 bytes).  By default 64 K of[10;15Hbuffer space is used for each file (unless the file is a pipe; see the -B option).  The -b option specifies instead  that  n[11;15Hkilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file.  If n is -1, buffer space is unlimited; that is, the entire file can[12;15Hbe read into memory.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       -B or --auto-buffers[15;8H       By default, when data is read from a pipe, buffers are allocated automatically as needed.  If a large amount of data is read[16;15Hfrom the pipe, this can cause a large amount of memory to be allocated.  The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[17;15Hbuffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe.  Warning: use[18;15Hof  -B  can  result  in erroneous display, since only the most recently viewed part of the piped data is kept in memory; any[19;15Hearlier data is lost.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -c or --clear-screen[22;8H       Causes full screen repaints to be painted from the top line down.  By default, full screen repaints are  done  by  scrolling[23;15Hfrom the bottom of the screen.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       -C or --CLEAR-SCREEN[26;8H       Same as -c, for compatibility with older versions of less.[27;1H[K[28;1H       -d or --dumb[29;8H       The  -d  option suppresses the error message normally displayed if the terminal is dumb; that is, lacks some important capaâ€[30;15Hbility, such as the ability to clear the screen or scroll backward.  The -d option does not otherwise change the behavior of[31;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[32;1H[K[33;1H       -Dxcolor or --color=xcolor[34;8H       [MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[35;15Hbeing set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period.   The[36;15Hfirst number selects the foreground color and the second selects the background color of the text.  A single number N is the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;18Hand including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hincluding the target line. If it is necessary to scroll backward more than n lines, the screen[6;15His repainted in a forward direction instead.  (If the terminal does  not  have  the  ability  to  scroll  backward,  -h0  is[7;15Himplied.)[K[9;9Hi or --ignore-case[10;22H searches  to  ignore case; that is, uppercase and lowercase are considered identical.  This option is ignored if any[11;15Huppercase letters appear in the search pattern; in other words, if a pattern contains uppercase letters,  then  that  search[12;1H              does not ignore case.[13;1H[K[14;8H-I or --IGNORE-CASE[K[15;1H              Like -i, but searches ignore case even if the pattern contains uppercase letters.[16;1H[K[17;8H-jn or --jump-target=n[K[18;15HSpecifies  a  line  on the screen where the "target" line is to be positioned.  The target line is the line specified by any[19;15Hcommand to search for a pattern, jump to a line number, jump to a file percentage or jump to a tag.  The screen line may  be[20;1H              specified  by  a number: the top line on the screen is 1, the next is 2, and so on.  The number may be negative to specify a[21;8H       line relative to the bottom of the screen: the bottom line on the screen is -1, the second to the bottom is -2, and  so  on.[22;15HAlternately,  the  screen line may be specified as a fraction of the height of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5[23;1H              is in the middle of the screen, .3 is three tenths down from the first line, and so on.  If the line is specified as a fracâ€[24;8H       tion, the actual line number is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the target line remains at the specâ€[25;15Hified fraction of the screen height.  If any form of the -j option is used, repeated forward searches (invoked with  "n"  or[26;15H"N")  begin  at  the line immediately after the target line, and repeated backward searches begin at the target line, unless[27;15Hchanged by -a or -A.  For example, if "-j4" is used, the target line is the fourth line on the screen, so  forward  searches[28;1H              begin at the fifth line on the screen.  However nonrepeated searches (invoked with "/" or "?")  always begin at the start or[29;8H       end of the current screen respectively.[30;1H[K[31;1H       -J or --status-column[32;8H       Displays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[33;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[36;1H              Causes  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[36;1H[1;8H       The -G option suppresses all highlighting of strings found by search commands.[2;1H[K[3;1H       -hn or --max-back-scroll=n[4;8H       Specifies a maximum number of lines to scroll backward.  If it is necessary to scroll backward more than n lines, the screen[5;15His repainted in a forward direction instead. For example, if "-j4" is used, the target line is the fourth line on the screen, so  forward  searches[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbegin at the fifth line on the screen.  However nonrepeated searches (invoked with "/" or "?")  always begin at the start or[36;1H[36;1H[2;15Hend of the current screen respectively.[K[3;1H[K[4;8H-J or --status-column[K[5;15HDisplays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[6;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[7;1H[K[8;8H-kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[K[9;15HCauses  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[10;1H              LESSKEY or LESSKEY_SYSTEM environment variable is set, or if a lesskey file is found in a standard place (see KEY BINDINGS),[11;8H       it is also used as a lesskey file.[12;1H[K[13;8H-K or --quit-on-intr[K[14;1H              Causes  less  to exit immediately (with status 2) when an interrupt character (usually ^C) is typed.  Normally, an interrupt[15;8H       character causes less to stop whatever it is doing and return to its command prompt.  Note that use of this option makes  it[16;15Himpossible to return to the command prompt from the "F" command.[K[17;1H[K[18;8H-L or --no-lessopen[K[19;1H              Ignore  the  LESSOPEN  environment  variable (see the INPUT PREPROCESSOR section below).  This option can be set from within[20;8H       less, but it will apply only to files opened subsequently, not to the file which is currently open.[21;1H[K[22;8H-m or --long-prompt[K[23;15HCauses less to prompt verbosely (like more), with the percent into the file.  By default, less prompts with a colon.[25;9HM or --LONG-PROMPT[26;15HCauses less to prompt even more verbosely than more.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       -n or --line-numbers[29;8H       Suppresses line numbers.  The default (to use line numbers) may cause less to run more slowly in some cases, especially with[30;15Ha  very  large  input file.  Suppressing line numbers with the -n option will avoid this problem.  Using line numbers means:[31;1H              the line number will be displayed in the verbose prompt and in the = command, and the v command will pass the  current  line[32;8H       number to the editor (see also the discussion of LESSEDIT in PROMPTS below).[33;1H[K[34;1H       -N or --LINE-NUMBERS[35;8H       Causes a line number to be displayed at the beginning of each line in the display.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;15Hend of the current screen respectively.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -J or --status-column[4;8H       Displays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[5;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       -kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[8;8H       Causes  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[9;15HLESSKEY or LESSKEY_SYSTEM environment variable is set, or if a lesskey file is found in a standard place (see KEY BINDINGS),[10;15Hit is also used as a lesskey file.[K[11;1H[K[12;1H       -K or --quit-on-intr[13;8H       Causes  less  to exit immediately (with status 2) when an interrupt character (usually ^C) is typed.  Normally, an interrupt[14;15Hcharacter causes less to stop whatever it is doing and return to its command prompt. This option can be set from within[19;15Hless, but it will apply only to files opened subsequently, not to the file which is currently open.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -m or --long-prompt[22;8H       Causes less to prompt verbosely (like more), with the percent into the file.  By default, less prompts with a colon.[23;1H[K[24;1H       -M or --LONG-PROMPT[25;8H       Causes less to prompt even more verbosely than more.[26;1H[K[27;1H       -n or --line-numbers[28;8H       Suppresses line numbers.  The default (to use line numbers) may cause less to run more slowly in some cases, especially with[29;15Ha  very  large  input file.  Suppressing line numbers with the -n option will avoid this problem. This option would normally  be  put  in  the  LESS[28;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command.  Such an option must either be the last option in[29;1H              the LESS variable, or be terminated by a dollar sign.[30;8H        -Ps followed by a string changes the default (short) prompt to that string.[31;15H -Pm changes the medium (-m) prompt.[K[32;15H -PM changes the long (-M) prompt.[33;1H               -Ph changes the prompt for the help screen.[34;8H        -P= changes the message printed by the = command.[35;15H -Pw changes the message printed while waiting for data (in the F command).  All prompt strings consist  of  a  sequence  of[36;15Hletters and special escape sequences. All prompt strings consist  of  a  sequence  of[28;15Hletters and special escape sequences.  See the section on PROMPTS for more details.[29;1H[K[30;8H-q or --quiet or --silent[K[31;15HCauses  moderately "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is not rung if an attempt is made to scroll past the end of the file[32;15Hor before the beginning of the file.  If the terminal has a "visual bell", it is used instead.  The bell  will  be  rung  on[33;15Hcertain other errors, such as typing an invalid character.  The default is to ring the terminal bell in all such cases.[34;1H[K[35;8H-Q or --QUIET or --SILENT[K[36;1H              Causes totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[36;1H[1;8H       Causes a line number to be displayed at the beginning of each line in the display.[2;1H[K[3;1H       -ofilename or --log-file=filename[4;8H       Causes less to copy its input to the named file as it is being viewed. If the file already exists, less will ask for confirmation before overwriting it.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       -Ofilename or --LOG-FILE=filename[8;8H       The -O option is like -o, but it will overwrite an existing file without asking for confirmation.[9;1H[K[10;1H              If no log file has been specified, the -o and -O options can be used from within less to specify a log file.  Without a file[11;15Hname, they will simply report the name of the log file.  The "s" command is equivalent to specifying -o from within less.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       -ppattern or --pattern=pattern[14;8H       The -p option on the command line is equivalent to specifying +/pattern; that is, it tells less to start at the first occurâ€[15;15Hrence of pattern in the file.[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       -Pprompt or --prompt=prompt[18;8H       Provides a way to tailor the three prompt styles to your own preference.  This option would normally  be  put  in  the  LESS[19;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command.  Such an option must either be the last option in[20;15Hthe LESS variable, or be terminated by a dollar sign.[K[21;15H -Ps followed by a string changes the default (short) prompt to that string.[22;18Hm changes the medium (-m) prompt.[K[23;18HM changes the long (-M) prompt.[K[24;18Hh changes the prompt for the help screen.[25;18H= changes the message printed by the = command.[26;18Hw changes the message printed while waiting for data (in the F command).  All prompt strings consist  of  a  sequence  of[27;15Hletters and special escape sequences.  See the section on PROMPTS for more details.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       -q or --quiet or --silent[30;8H       Causes  moderately "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is not rung if an attempt is made to scroll past the end of the file[31;15Hor before the beginning of the file.  If the terminal has a "visual bell", it is used instead.  The bell  will  be  rung  on[32;15Hcertain other errors, such as typing an invalid character.  The default is to ring the terminal bell in all such cases.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       -Q or --QUIET or --SILENT[35;8H       Causes totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -ofilename or --log-file=filename[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes less to copy its input to the named file as it is being viewed.  This applies only when the input file is a pipe, not[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --41%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15Han ordinary file.  If the file already exists, less will ask for confirmation before overwriting it.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -Ofilename or --LOG-FILE=filename[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       The -O option is like -o, but it will overwrite an existing file without asking for confirmation.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              If no log file has been specified, the -o and -O options can be used from within less to specify a log file.  Without a file[3;8H       name, they will simply report the name of the log file.  The "s" command is equivalent to specifying -o from within less.[4;1H[K[5;8H-ppattern or --pattern=pattern[K[6;1H              The -p option on the command line is equivalent to specifying +/pattern; that is, it tells less to start at the first occurâ€[7;8H       rence of pattern in the file.[8;1H[K[9;1H       -Pprompt or --prompt=prompt[10;15HProvides a way to tailor the three prompt styles to your own preference. Such an option must either be the last option in[12;1H              the LESS variable, or be terminated by a dollar sign.[13;8H        -Ps followed by a string changes the default (short) prompt to that string.[14;15H -Pm changes the medium (-m) prompt.[K[15;15H -PM changes the long (-M) prompt.[16;1H               -Ph changes the prompt for the help screen.[17;8H        -P= changes the message printed by the = command.[18;15H -Pw changes the message printed while waiting for data (in the F command).  All prompt strings consist  of  a  sequence  of[19;15Hletters and special escape sequences.  See the section on PROMPTS for more details.[K[20;1H[K[21;8H-q or --quiet or --silent[K[22;15HCauses  moderately "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is not rung if an attempt is made to scroll past the end of the file[23;15Hor before the beginning of the file.  If the terminal has a "visual bell", it is used instead.  The bell  will  be  rung  on[24;15Hcertain other errors, such as typing an invalid character.  The default is to ring the terminal bell in all such cases.[25;1H[K[26;8H-Q or --QUIET or --SILENT[K[27;15HCauses totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[K[29;9Hr or --raw-control-chars[30;22H"raw" control characters to be displayed.  The default is to display control characters using the caret notation; for[31;15Hexample, a control-A (octal 001) is displayed as "^A".  Warning: when the -r option is used, less cannot keep track  of  the[32;15Hactual  appearance  of  the screen (since this depends on how the screen responds to each type of control character).  Thus,[33;1H              various display problems may result, such as long lines being split in the wrong place.[34;1H[K[35;8H-R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[K[36;1H              Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form. Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[28;8H       correctly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[29;1H[K[30;15H     ESC [ ... m[K[31;1H[K[32;15Hwhere  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[33;1H              color escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor.  You can make less think that characters other than "m"  can  end[34;8H       ANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[35;15Hcolor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[36;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[36;1H[1;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command. ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[28;1H[K[29;1H                   ESC [ ... m[30;1H[K[31;1H              where  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[32;15Hcolor escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor. And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[28;1H              and the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[29;1H[K[30;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[31;15HCauses consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[K[32;1H[K[33;8H-S or --chop-long-lines[K[34;15HCauses  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[35;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[36;1H              on the next line.[36;1H[1;15Hletters and special escape sequences. The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[28;1H              on the next line.[29;1H[K[30;8H-ttag or --tag=tag[K[31;1H              The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[32;8H       must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[33;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a comâ€[34;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/softâ€[35;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[36;1H              a new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[36;1H[1;8H       Causes totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[2;1H[K[3;1H       -r or --raw-control-chars[4;8H       Causes "raw" control characters to be displayed. And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[19;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[22;8H       Causes consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[23;1H[K[24;1H       -S or --chop-long-lines[25;8H       Causes  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[26;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[27;15Hon the next line.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       -ttag or --tag=tag[30;8H       The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[31;15Hmust be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[32;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a comâ€[33;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/softâ€[34;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[35;15Ha new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -r or --raw-control-chars[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes "raw" control characters to be displayed.  The default is to display control characters using the caret notation; for[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --44%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15Hexample, a control-A (octal 001) is displayed as "^A".  Warning: when the -r option is used, less cannot keep track  of  the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hactual  appearance  of  the screen (since this depends on how the screen responds to each type of control character).  Thus,[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hvarious display problems may result, such as long lines being split in the wrong place.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H       -R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[3;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[4;15Hcorrectly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[5;1H[K[6;15H     ESC [ ... m[K[7;1H[K[8;1H              where  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[9;8H       color escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor.  You can make less think that characters other than "m"  can  end[10;15HANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[11;17Hlor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[12;1H              and the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[13;1H[K[14;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[15;15HCauses consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[K[16;1H[K[17;8H-S or --chop-long-lines[K[18;15HCauses  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[19;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[20;1H              on the next line.[21;1H[K[22;8H-ttag or --tag=tag[K[23;1H              The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[24;8H       must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[25;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a comâ€[26;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/softâ€[27;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[28;1H              a new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[29;1H[K[30;8H-Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[K[31;15HSpecifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[K[32;1H[K[33;8H-u or --underline-special[K[34;15HCauses backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[35;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[36;1H[1;1H       -R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[2;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form. Also, backspaces which[35;1H              appear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[36;8H       boldface  capability. Also, backspaces which[34;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[35;15Hboldface  capability. Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option.  Text which is overstruck[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hcolor escape sequence. If only one n is specified, tab stops are set at multiples of n.  If multiple values  separated  by  commas[36;15Hare  specified, tab stops are set at those positions, and then continue with the same spacing as the last two.  For example,[36;1H[1;15Ha new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[4;8H       Specifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[5;1H[K[6;1H       -u or --underline-special[7;8H       Causes backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[8;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[9;1H[K[10;1H       -U or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[11;8H       Causes  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[12;15Hthe -r option.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  speâ€[15;15Hcially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[16;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[17;15Hboldface  capability. The entire line is highlighted, unless the -J option is[28;15Hin effect, in which case only the status column is highlighted.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       -W or --HILITE-UNREAD[31;8H       Like -w, but temporarily highlights the first new line after any forward movement command larger than one line.[32;1H[K[33;1H       -xn,... or --tabs=n,...[34;8H       Sets tab stops.  If only one n is specified, tab stops are set at multiples of n.  If multiple values  separated  by  commas[35;15Hare  specified, tab stops are set at those positions, and then continue with the same spacing as the last two.  For example,[36;15H-x9,17 will set tabs at positions 9, 17, 25, 33, etc.  The default for n is 8.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Specifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --47%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H       -u or --underline-special[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -U or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              Causes  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[3;8H       the -r option.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  speâ€[6;8H       cially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[7;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[8;15Hboldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately folâ€[9;1H              lowed by a newline are deleted.  Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option.  Text which is overstruck[10;8H       or underlined can be searched for if neither -u nor -U is in effect.[11;1H[K[12;8H-V or --version[K[13;1H              Displays the version number of less.[14;1H[K[15;8H-w or --hilite-unread[K[16;15HTemporarily highlights the first "new" line after a forward movement of a full page.  The first "new" line is the line immeâ€[17;15Hdiately following the line previously at the bottom of the screen.  Also highlights the target line after a g or p  command.[18;15HThe highlight is removed at the next command which causes movement.  The entire line is highlighted, unless the -J option is[19;15Hin effect, in which case only the status column is highlighted.[K[21;9HW or --HILITE-UNREAD[22;15HLike -w, but temporarily highlights the first new line after any forward movement command larger than one line.[24;9Hxn,... or --tabs=n,...[25;15HSets tab stops. This is  sometimes  desirable  if[31;15Hthe deinitialization string does something unnecessary, like clearing the screen.[K[33;9Hyn or --max-forw-scroll=n[34;16Hpecifies  a  maximum number of lines to scroll forward.  If it is necessary to scroll forward more than n lines, the screen[35;15His repainted instead.  The -c or -C option may be used to repaint from the top of the screen if desired. This option causes lines after end of file to be disâ€[25;15Hplayed as blank lines.[K[26;1H[K[27;8H-# or --shift[K[28;15HSpecifies the default number of positions to scroll horizontally in the RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.   If  the  number[29;16Hpecified  is zero, it sets the default number of positions to one half of the screen width.  Alternately, the number may be[30;15Hspecified as a fraction of the width of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5 is half of the  screen  width,  .3  is[31;1H              three  tenths  of  the screen width, and so on.  If the number is specified as a fraction, the actual number of scroll posiâ€[32;8H       tions is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the actual scroll remains at the specified fraction of  the[33;15Hscreen width.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       --follow-name[36;8H       Normally,  if  the  input file is renamed while an F command is executing, less will continue to display the contents of the[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --50%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15Hthe deinitialization string does something unnecessary, like clearing the screen.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -yn or --max-forw-scroll=n[4;8H       Specifies  a  maximum number of lines to scroll forward.
